awd_titl_txt: Conference Proposal: Kylerec Student Workshop in Symplectic and Contact Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation award provides partial support for the next two Kylerec student workshops to be held in 2018 and 2019. The Kylerec workshop aims to introduce aspiring mathematicians in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry and from many institutions to vibrant areas of research, fostering collaboration, forming strong research ties between young researchers, and thus promoting future collaboration and research. The workshop is specifically designed to encourage the development of a diverse group of researchers in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry. It is a week-long intensive workshop, in which all activities occur under one roof. The lectures are delivered by the graduate student participants with the help of three to four mentors, who are emerging expert researchers in the field. This setup enhances communication skills, encourages active involvement of the participants and forging new collaborations.

In 2018, the workshop will be held from May 25 to May 31 in the Leavenworth Lodge in Leavenworth, WA, and will be mentored by Thomas Kragh (Uppsala), Roberta Guadagni (U. Penn.), Jingyu Zhao (Brandeis) and Kyler Siegel (MIT). The topic is the nearby Lagrangian conjecture, which is a central open question about the symplectic topology of cotangent bundles, and has been a nexus for much of the recent technical development in the subject. The objective of this workshop is to understand the state of the art in this problem: including both the technical tools utilized, such as Fukaya categories, as well as some of the broader philosophy that has come out of work on this problem. Notes from the lectures and further information will be available on the website https://kylerec.wordpress.com/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported several editions of the Kylerec graduate student workshops. This workshop aims to introduce aspiring mathematicians in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry and from many institutions to vibrant areas of research, fostering collaboration, forming strong research ties between young researchers, and thus promoting future collaboration and research.

The workshop is specifically designed to encourage the development of a diverse group of researchers in the fields of symplectic and contact geometry. It is an annual week-long intensive workshop, in which all activities occur under one roof.

Each year, the workshop is organized by a group of 5 graduate students. The organizers select a topic from the field of symplectic and contact geometry, whose features highlight general developments in the understanding of symplectic and contact manifolds. Three or four junior researchers, experts in that topic, serve as mentors, and the rest of the participants in the Kylerec workshop are graduate students and a few may be postdoctoral fellows. 

This grant supported primarily the 2018 and 2019 workshops, and in small part the 2022 workshop; unfortunately, the 2020 and 2021 workshops had to be cancelled/postponed due to the pandemic.

The 2018 Kylerec workshop took place May 25-31, 2018, and its main topic was symplectic geometry of cotangent bundles, in particular focusing on recent progress related to Arnold's conjecture on closed exact Lagrangians in cotangent bundles, often known as the Nearby Lagrangian Conjecture. 

The 2019 Kylerec workshop took place May 31-June 6, 2019, and its main topic was "sheafy symplectic topology", in particular focusing on recent progress related to the arborealization program and to local computations of wrapped Fukaya categories.

The 2022 Kylerec workshop took place in person during the period June 19-23, 2022, and the main topic was "Quantitative symplectic geometry". 

The Kylerec workshop has a strong focus on the development of young researchers. During the Kylerec workshop, almost all participants, consisting of graduate students and postdocs, deliver the talks. Mentors are assigned to speakers, to help them prepare their talks. It appears that this collaboration was very fruitful, with many speakers reporting interesting exchanges with their mentors.

This is in stark contrast to the more typical workshops in which lectures are given primarily by established researchers. This immersive experience is key to our operating principle: it puts early career mathematicians at the very center of the workshop, as opposed to remaining a passive audience. Having participants learn their piece of the puzzle before the workshop greatly facilitates the audience's understanding of the material, and encourages active participation during discussion sessions.

Furthermore, Kylerec offers an opportunity for young researchers in topology, geometry and specifically in symplectic and contact geometry, from different institutions to meet, connect and actively learn together. By having discussion sessions with open problems we hope every participant left the workshop with questions to think about in the future as well as the potential to form research collaborations with other participants.


Last Modified: 01/04/2023
Modified by: Eleny-Nicoleta Ionel
